data.title: The best family movies on Disney+ right now
data.meta_description: The best family movies on Disney+ right now include Moana, Cinderella, The Little Mermaid, and more.
data.text:
The best family movies on Disney+ are a mixture of animated classics, live-action adaptations, and iconic blockbusters. The Disney library is home to several iconic brands and IP, from Marvel and Star Wars to Pixar and The Muppets. After the acquisition of 20th Century Fox, Disney’s vault expanded even more with the additions of the X-Men, Planet of the Apes, and Avatar franchises. From Captain America and Ariel to Goofy and Nemo, Disney+ has hundreds of family films to satisfy every type of audience.

Disney+ is arguably the best streaming service for family movies. Below, you’ll find an assortment of animated smash hits like Moana, as well as updated live-action adaptations of animated classics like Cinderella. Whatever movie your family prefers, chances are you’ll find something on the list for your next movie night.

For more Disney+ content, we selected the best movies on Disney+ to watch right now. Additionally, we’ve also rounded up the best family movies on Amazon Prime Video and the best family movies on Netflix if you don’t find what you’re looking for on Disney+.

Recently added to this list

Moana

pg 2016

Cinderella

pg 2015

Cool Runnings

pg 1993

Moana (2016)

81%

7.6/10

pg

107m

Genre

Adventure, Comedy, Family, Animation

Stars

Auli'i Cravalho, Dwayne Johnson, Rachel House

Directed by

John Musker, Ron Clements

Watch on Disney+

Moana has all the ingredients for a successful Disney film: a heartwarming story, memorable characters, and infectious music. On the island of Motunui, Moana (Auliʻi Cravalho), the teenage daughter of the village chief, is chosen by the ocean to restore the heart of the god, Te Fiti. On her journey, Moana meets Maui (Dwayne Johnson), a shapeshifting demigod who joins the young girl on her journey. With danger at every turn, Moana sets sail on a journey to return the heart to Te Futi. Yet, this quest becomes one of self-discovery as Moana discovers her true purpose in life along the way.

Cinderella (2015)

67%

6.9/10

pg

105m

Genre

Romance, Fantasy, Family, Drama

Stars

Lily James, Cate Blanchett, Richard Madden

Directed by

Kenneth Branagh

Watch on Disney+

One of Disney’s most famous princesses received the live-action treatment in 2015’s Cinderella. In this version, Ella (Lily James) is a thoughtful girl living with her father (Ben Chaplin) and new stepmother, Lady Tremaine (Cate Blanchett). After the sudden death of her father, Ella becomes the family’s maid, serving her evil stepmother and stepsisters. Ella’s chance for a better life comes in the form of a palace ball, where she hopes to rekindle her connection with Prince Kit (Game of Thrones star Richard Madden), the dashing young gentleman she met in the woods. Despite her cruel stepmother banning her from going, Ella receives aid from a fairy godmother (Helena Bonham Carter), who helps Ella get to the ball before it’s too late.

Cool Runnings (1993)

60%

7.0/10

pg

98m

Genre

Comedy, Adventure, Drama

Stars

Leon, Doug E. Doug, Rawle D. Lewis

Directed by

Jon Turteltaub

Watch on Disney+

Feel the rhythm and feel the rhyme because get on up, it’s bobsled time. The inspirational story of the Jamaican national bobsled team at the 1988 Winter Olympics comes to life in Cool Runnings. Derice Bannock (Leon) dreams of running the 100-meter dash at the Olympics for his home country of Jamaica. Unfortunately, Derice fails to qualify after a freak accident during the race. Although Derice’s Summer Olympic dream is dead, he can still qualify for the Winter Olympics. Enter Irving Blitzer (John Candy), a disgraced bobsledding coach who lives in Jamaica. Despite having no bobsled experience, Derice convinces Irving to coach him and three other Jamaicans — Sanka Coffie (Doug E. Doug), Junior Bevil (Rawle D. Lewis), and Yul Brenner (Malik Yoba) — as they try to qualify for the Winter Olympics.

Wish (2023)

47%

5.6/10

pg

95m

Genre

Animation, Family, Fantasy, Adventure

Stars

Ariana DeBose, Chris Pine, Alan Tudyk

Directed by

Chris Buck, Fawn Veerasunthorn

Watch on Disney+

Sometimes, wishes come true; you need to know where to look. In Disney’s Wish, all young Asha (Ariana DeBose) wants is for King Magnifico (Chris Pine) of the Kingdom of Roses to make her grandfather Sabino’s (Victor Garber) wish come true. Sabino’s wish is to inspire people. Viewing this request as a threat to his power, Magnifico denies Sabino’s wish and refuses to grant any of her family’s wishes. Upset with Magnifico’s decision, Asha runs away to a wishing tree from her past and wishes on a star. Much to her surprise, the star comes down from the sky as a light ball, which Asha names Star. The star uses its powers to give animals talking abilities. With Star on her side, Asha gains the confidence to take on Magnifico and save the world from his reign.

The Marvels (2023)

50%

5.5/10

pg-13

105m

Genre

Science Fiction, Adventure, Action

Stars

Brie Larson, Teyonah Parris, Iman Vellani

Directed by

Nia DaCosta

Watch on Disney+

Brie Larson is back for another go-around as Carol Danvers/Captain Marvel in The Marvels, the sequel to Captain Marvel. The Marvels opens with Danvers taking on the Kree and the Supreme Intelligence. Danvers’s actions inspire Kree’s new leader, Dar-Benn (Zawe Ashton), to create a new network for space travel with a Quantum Band. This wormhole threatens the S.A.B.E.R. space station run by Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson). When Danvers investigates one side of the network, it causes her powers to intertwine with teenager Kamala Khan/Ms. Marvel (Iman Vellani) and Captain Monica Rambeau (Teyonah Parris). Danvers, Khan, and Rambeau must learn to harness their powers and work together to stop Dar-Benn. The fate of the universe is at stake, and only the Marvels can save it.

Avatar: The Way of Water (2022)

67%

7.6/10

pg-13

192m

Genre

Science Fiction, Adventure, Action

Stars

Sam Worthington, Zoe Saldaña, Sigourney Weaver

Directed by

James Cameron

Watch on Disney+

If you didn’t think James Cameron could raise the bar for Pandora after Avatar, think again. 15 years have passed since the events of Avatar, and Jake Sully (Sam Worthington) is now the leader of the Omatikaya clan. Jake is married to Ney’tiri, and together, the couple has four children. Unfortunately for the Sully family, the RDA returns to colonize Pandora. To make matters worse, Colonel Miles Quaritch (Stephen Lang) is now a recombinant and wants nothing more than to exact his revenge on Jake. To protect his family, Jake and his family leave the Omatikaya for the ocean-dwelling Metkayina tribe. As Jake learns the ways of the water, he knows Quaritch will not stop until he gets another fight. The war between the Na’vi and humans has only just begun.

Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)

58%

6.6/10

pg-13

155m

Genre

Adventure, Action

Stars

Harrison Ford, Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Mads Mikkelsen

Directed by

James Mangold

Watch on Disney+

For one last time, Harrison Ford is donning his hat and cracking his bullwhip in Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny. The fifth entry in the franchise picks up in 1969 with Indiana Jones (Ford) in the last phase of his life. Preparing for retirement from teaching, Indy is visited by Helena Shaw (Phoebe Waller-Bridge), Indy’s goddaughter, who seeks information about an ancient dial that facilitates time travel. Indy came across this dial in the 1940s and kept half of it to keep it away from the Nazis, who could potentially alter the course of history with both halves. Jürgen Voller (Mads Mikkelsen), a former Nazi who now works for NASA, sets out to steal both pieces of the dial. With Helena’s help, Indy must go on one final adventure to retrieve the dial and save the world.

Haunted Mansion (2023)

47%

6.1/10

pg-13

123m

Genre

Fantasy, Comedy, Horror, Family

Stars

Rosario Dawson, Chase W. Dillon, LaKeith Stanfield

Directed by

Justin Simien

Watch on Disney+

One of Walt Disney’s most iconic attractions serves as the inspiration for Haunted Mansion. Single mom Gabbie (Rosario Dawson) and her son Travis (Chase W. Dillon) move from New York to New Orleans after purchasing Gracey Manor, an old mansion they wish to turn into a bed and breakfast. However, Gabbie and Travis learn the mansion is haunted by ghosts. Wanting to rid their new house of ghosts, Gabbie seeks help from a group of paranormal experts, including Ben (LaKeith Stanfield), a ghost tour guide, Father Kent (Owen Wilson), a priest and exorcist, Harriet (Tiffany Haddish), a psychic, and Bruce Davis, a college professor. Together, the group must rid the mansion of ghosts, or they will succumb to the supernatural creatures and remain at Gracey Manor forever.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 (2023)

64%

7.9/10

pg-13

150m

Genre

Science Fiction, Adventure, Action

Stars

Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldaña, Dave Bautista

Directed by

James Gunn

Watch on Disney+

After a decade together, it’s time to say goodbye to your favorite ragtag group of superheroes in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3. Still reeling over the loss of Gamora (Zoe Saldaña) and his lack of relationship with 20214 Gamora, a depressed Peter Quill (Chris Pratt) drowns his sorrows in alcohol at the Guardians’ new headquarters on Knowhere. One day, the Guardians are attacked by Adam Warlock (Will Poulter), who severely injures Rocket (Bradley Cooper). To save Rocket from dying, they must travel to OrgoCorp, the company that created Rocket, to override his killswitch. The Guardians seek help from 2014 Gamora and the Ravagers to infiltrate OrgoCorp, where they must battle the High Evolutionary (Chukwudi Iwuji), the cyborg scientist responsible for experimenting on Rocket. The dangerous mission will require the Guardians to be at their best as they prepare to make the ultimate sacrifice to save Rocket.

The Little Mermaid (2023)

59%

7.2/10

pg

135m

Genre

Adventure, Family, Fantasy, Romance

Stars

Halle Bailey, Jonah Hauer-King, Daveed Diggs

Directed by

Rob Marshall

Watch on Disney+

Ariel is the latest Disney princess to receive the live-action treatment in The Little Mermaid. Based on the 1989 animated film, The Little Mermaid stars Halle Bailey, the mermaid princess and youngest daughter of King Triton (Javier Bardem). Ariel wants to be part of the human world, but her father forbids her from exploring above the sea since Ariel’s mother was killed by a human. Ariel saves Prince Eric (Jonah Hauer-King) from a shipwreck one night. Wanting to learn more about Eric and the human world, Ariel makes a deal with the sea witch, Ursula (Melissa McCarthy): turn into a human for three days and receive “true love’s kiss” to remain in that world. If that doesn’t happen, Ariel will transform back into a mermaid and be claimed by Ursula.

Elemental (2023)

58%

7.0/10

pg

102m

Genre

Animation, Comedy, Family, Fantasy, Romance

Stars

Leah Lewis, Mamoudou Athie, Ronnie del Carmen

Directed by

Peter Sohn

Watch on Disney+

Travel to the animated world of Element City in Pixar’s Elemental. In the city, various elements – fire, water, land, and air – coexist and represent different social classes. Ember Lumen (Leah Lewis) is the daughter of two fire elements who emigrated to Element City. The family now runs a convenience store, which Ember hopes to run someday after her father retires. On a day when she gets to run the shop by herself, Ember has a tantrum that bursts a pipe and floods the basement. Wade Ripple (Mamoudou Athie), a water element, is a city inspector sent to report the leak. Wade decides to help Ember fix the problem and save the store. While spending time together, Ember and Wade fall in love, but outside forces will try to tear these two elements apart.

Chang Can Dunk (2023)

77%

6.4/10

pg

108m

Genre

Family, Comedy, Drama

Stars

Bloom Li, Ben Wang, Zoe Renee

Directed by

Jingyi Shao

Watch on Disney+

Chang (Bloom Li) is an unpopular Asian American high school sophomore. Despite being in the band, Chang’s top passion is basketball. However, his former friend-turned-rival Matt (Chase Liefeld) makes high school life hard for Chang. After being humiliated at a party, Chang bets Matt he can dunk a basketball by homecoming. Since Chang can’t dunk, he seeks help from Deandre Cooke (Dexter Darden), a YouTuber who films himself dunking. Deandre agrees to train Chang and teach him how to dunk in exchange for help with his YouTube videos. Chang ends up winning the bet, and his popularity soars. However, it comes at a price, forcing Chang to examine his priorities in this coming-of-age story.

Peter Pan & Wendy (2023)

61%

4.4/10

pg

106m

Genre

Family, Fantasy, Action, Adventure

Stars

Alexander Molony, Ever Anderson, Jude Law

Directed by

David Lowery

Watch on Disney+

The tale of the boy who refuses to grow up gets the live-action treatment once again in Peter Pan & Wendy. Wendy Darling (Ever Anderson) is a London girl afraid to leave for boarding school and fears the idea of growing up. Peter Pan (Alexander Molony) and the magical fairy Tinker Bell (Yara Shahidi) flies to London to rescue Wendy and her two brothers from adulthood. Peter flies with Wendy and the boys to Neverland, a place where kids never grow up. In Neverland, Wendy meets Peter’s followers, the Lost Boys. Wendy also runs into Captain Hook (Jude Law), the sinister pirate who seeks revenge against Peter Pan after the Lost Boys’ leader cut off his hand and fed it to a crocodile. With beautiful visuals and new plot twists, Peter Pan & Wendy is a worthy adaptation of a children’s classic.

Hocus Pocus 2 (2022)

56%

6.9/10

pg

107m

Genre

Fantasy, Comedy, Family

Stars

Bette Midler, Sarah Jessica Parker, Kathy Najimy

Directed by

Anne Fletcher

Watch on Disney+

The Sanderson Sisters head back to Salem with a vengeance in Hocus Pocus 2. Serving as the sequel to 1993’s Hocus Pocus, the second Hocus Pocus is set in 2022 and follows two high school friends, Becca (Whitney Peak) and Becca (Belissa Escobedo). With Halloween and Becca’s 16th birthday approaching, the friends visit a Salem magic shop, where they are gifted a special birthday candle. The birthday present, however, is a Black Flame Candle, so the girls accidentally resurrect the Sanderson witches: Winnie (Bette Midler), Sarah (And Just Like That‘s Sarah Jessica Parker), and Mary (Kathy Najimy). The girls must team up with their estranged friend Cassie (Lilia Buckingham) to stop the Sanderson sisters from exacting their revenge on Salem. Hocus Pocus 2 satisfies both a new, younger audience looking for a new Halloween treat, and an older demographic wanting to relieve the nostalgia from the first film.

Disenchanted (2022)

50%

5.7/10

pg

120m

Genre

Comedy, Family, Fantasy

Stars

Amy Adams, Patrick Dempsey, Maya Rudolph

Directed by

Adam Shankman

Watch on Disney+

In Enchanted, the formerly animated princess known as Giselle (Amy Adams) found her happily ever after in New York as the wife of Robert Philip (Patrick Dempsey). But not every happy ending lasts forever. In the long-awaited sequel, Disenchanted, Giselle is hurt when her stepdaughter, Morgan (Gabriella Baldacchino), emotionally pulls away from her. Even Robert admits to being dissatisfied with the way their lives are going despite a move to the suburbs. Out of a desire to make everyone happy, Giselle uses some magic from Andalasia to make their lives more like a fairy tale. And it works all too well, because now Giselle is slowly becoming a wicked stepmother.

Disenchanted | Official Trailer | Disney+

The Santa Clause (1994)

57%

6.5/10

pg

97m

Genre

Fantasy, Drama, Comedy, Family

Stars

Tim Allen, Judge Reinhold, Wendy Crewson

Directed by

John Pasquin

Watch on Disney+

We all have a little Santa in us around Christmas time. The problem with Scott Calvin (Tim Allen) is that he has too much Santa in him! In Disney’s The Santa Clause, Scott inadvertently causes the death of the previous Santa. And by putting on Santa’s outfit and continuing his mission, Scott finds himself literally transforming into the new Santa. This causes havoc with Scott’s daily life, as his ex-wife, Laura Miller (Wendy Crewson), and her husband, Neil Miller (Judge Reinhold), use that against Scott to keep him from having custody of his son, Charlie (Eric Lloyd).

The Santa Clause (1994) Trailer #1 | Movieclips Classic Trailers

Noelle (2020)

48%

6.3/10

g

100m

Genre

Family, Comedy, Fantasy

Stars

Anna Kendrick, Bill Hader, Kingsley Ben-Adir

Directed by

Marc Lawrence

Watch on Disney+

There must be a multiverse of Disney Santas because Noelle is also about the succession of Santa Claus. Except, Noelle Kringle (Anna Kendrick) is definitely not the daughter of Scott Calvin. Instead, she’s the daughter of the late Kris Kringle, and brother of the next Santa, Nick Kringle (Bill Hader). However, Nick has neither the desire nor the aptitude to take over his father’s role. And when Nick abandons his responsibilities at the North Pole, it falls on Noelle to track down her brother and bring him back in time to save Christmas.

Noelle | Official Trailer | Disney+ | Streaming November 12

Brave (2012)

69%

7.1/10

pg

93m

Genre

Animation, Adventure, Comedy, Family, Action, Fantasy

Stars

Kelly Macdonald, Billy Connolly, Emma Thompson

Directed by

Brenda Chapman, Mark Andrews

Watch on Disney+

Brave was the first Pixar movie to feature a princess in the leading role. But Merida (Kelly Macdonald) isn’t like a lot of the other Disney princesses. She is completely horrified by the notion of being wed to anyone, especially when the clans come together to let the princes compete for her hand. Merida’s actions shame the other clans and cause a rift with her mother, Queen Elinor (Emma Thompson). Merida compounds the problem when she seeks a magical solution that somehow turns her mother into a bear. And if Merida and Elinor can’t find a cure then the queen will be forever trapped in her new form.

Brave Trailer

Lightyear (2022)

60%

5.5/10

pg

105m

Genre

Animation, Science Fiction, Adventure, Action, Family

Stars

Chris Evans, Keke Palmer, Peter Sohn

Directed by

Angus MacLane

Watch on Disney+

Pixar’s Lightyear is definitely a learning experience for Buzz Lightyear (Chris Evans). The Space Ranger’s instincts continually get the better of him, and his mistakes leave an entire colony of men and women stranded on a hostile world. Buzz’s attempts to test a new fuel source only lead him to skip ahead into the future four years at a time, remaining young while his friends and colleagues grow old and perish. After his last test flight, Buzz discovers that the planet is under attack by alien robots called Zurg. He also meets Izzy Hawthorne (Keke Palmer), the granddaughter of his best friend, Alisha, and one of the only allies he has left in the fight against the invaders.

Lightyear | Official Trailer

Cheaper by the Dozen (2003)

46%

5.9/10

pg

98m

Genre

Comedy, Family

Stars

Steve Martin, Bonnie Hunt, Piper Perabo

Directed by

Shawn Levy

Watch on Disney+

Since Steve Martin is having a late-career renaissance with Only Murders in the Building on Hulu, it’s worth checking out Cheaper by the Dozen, one of Martin’s few films on Disney+. In this remake of the 1950s movie, Martin plays Tom Baker, the husband of Kate Baker (Bonnie Hunt), both of whom are the parents of 12 unruly kids. When Tom gets a job coaching college football and Kate goes on a book tour, their daughter Nora Baker (Piper Perabo) is left in charge alongside her kid-hating boyfriend, Hank (Ashton Kutcher). However, the other Baker children rebel, forcing Tom and Kate to put aside their careers and attempt to reconcile with the wants and needs of their kids.

Christopher Robin (2018)

60%

7.2/10

pg

104m

Genre

Adventure, Comedy, Family, Fantasy

Stars

Ewan McGregor, Hayley Atwell, Bronte Carmichael

Directed by

Marc Forster

Watch on Disney+

Everyone gets older and grows up, even Christopher Robin (Ewan McGregor). The boy who had such magical adventures in the Hundred Acre Wood has forgotten all about his old friends, Pooh Bear and Tigger (both voiced by Jim Cummings). But one day, Pooh dramatically reenters Christopher’s life and all of the old memories come flooding back. Together, they return to the Hundred Acre Wood and reunite with their pals after so many years away. Yet Christopher can’t stay in the past forever, and he will have to find a way to reconcile who he was as a boy with the man that he has become in the present.

Christopher Robin Official Trailer

Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers (2022)

66%

7/10

pg

99m

Genre

Animation, Family, Comedy, Adventure, Mystery

Stars

Andy Samberg, John Mulaney, KiKi Layne

Directed by

Akiva Schaffer

Watch on Disney+

Admittedly, some of the humor in Chip ‘n Dale: Rescue Rangers is going to go over the heads of younger viewers. Older members of the family will love the cameos, including the scene-stealing Ugly Sonic (Tim Robinson). But the heart of the film belongs to lifelong friends Chip (John Mulaney) and Dale (Andy Samberg), three decades after their professional falling out. When their mutual friend and former co-star, Monterey Jack (Eric Bana), goes missing, Chip reluctantly teams up with Dale to find him. KiKi Layne co-stars as a human detective named Ellie Steckler, and she breaks a few police regulations to help out her favorite cartoon heroes.

Official Trailer | Chip n’ Dale: Rescue Rangers | Disney+

Pinocchio (1940)

99%

7.5/10

g

88m

Genre

Animation, Family

Stars

Dickie Jones, Cliff Edwards, Christian Rub

Directed by

Ben Sharpsteen, William Roberts, Hamilton Luske, T. Hee, Wilfred Jackson, Jack Kinney, Norman Ferguson

Watch on Disney+

Disney+ has a live-action Pinocchio remake coming this year, which will surely make this list. However, Disney’s original Pinocchio is easily one of the greatest animated films ever created. That’s even more impressive considering that it was made 82 years ago, during the infancy of the medium. Dick Jones provides the voice of Pinocchio, a puppet who is brought to life by the Blue Fairy (Evelyn Venable) to be the son of a lonely toymaker, Geppetto (Christian Rub). Unfortunately, Pinocchio is a bit of a delinquent who has trouble telling right from wrong. That’s why Jiminy Cricket (Cliff Edwards) has to be Pinocchio’s conscience. Regardless, not even the good-hearted Jiminy can keep Pinocchio out of trouble for long.

Hollywood Stargirl (2022)

66%

5.7/10

pg

105m

Genre

Comedy, Romance, Music, Drama

Stars

Grace VanderWaal, Judy Greer, Elijah Richardson

Directed by

Julia Hart

Watch on Disney+

Stargirl has turned out to be a viable franchise among the Disney+ original films, and the first sequel, Hollywood Stargirl, didn’t need a theatrical release to earn a following. Grace VanderWaal reprises her role as Susan “Stargirl” Caraway as she and her mother, Ana Caraway (Judy Greer), move to Los Angeles. Stargirl’s voice and musical talents quickly pave the way for her career to begin, but she’s particularly interested in helping a former musician, Roxanne Martel (Uma Thurman), rediscover the passion she used to have. Stargirl also forms a close bond with Evan (Elijah Richardson), a young filmmaker who may want more than just a professional relationship with her.

Hollywood Stargirl | Official Trailer | Disney+

Sneakerella (2022)

4.5/10

110m

Genre

Music, Comedy, Family

Stars

Chosen Jacobs, Lexi Underwood, Kolton Stewart

Directed by

Elizabeth Allen Rosenbaum

Watch on Disney+

Disney loves a good Cinderella story. Beyond the animated original, there’s a live-action remake and two direct-to-video animated sequels currently streaming on Disney+. Sneakerella is also a Cinderella story, just not necessarily the same one we’ve seen so many times before. In this modernized tale, Chosen Jacobs stars as El, a teenager living with his stepfamily (and two bad stepbrothers) while quietly chasing his dream to become a sneaker designer. El soon forms a connection with Kira King (Lexi Underwood), but he is initially unaware that she is the daughter of a famous sneaker mogul, Darius King (John Salley). Can El find love and make his dreams come true? Sure he can, with a little bit of that Disney magic.

Sneakerella | Official Trailer | Disney+

A Goofy Movie (1995)

53%

6.9/10

Genre

Romance, Animation, Family, Comedy, Adventure

Stars

Bill Farmer, Jason Marsden, Rob Paulsen

Directed by

Kevin Lima

Watch on Disney+

Among the core trio of Disney characters, Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck seem like more obvious choices to headline their own film. And yet A Goofy Movie struck a chord with audiences and it has earned a fan following since its release. In this spinoff from the Goof Troop TV series, Goofy (Bill Farmer) is a single dad who has trouble connecting with his son, Max (Jason Marsden). As for Max, he’s worried that he’ll become an infamous klutz like his father. After Max impresses his crush, Roxanne (Kellie Martin), by pulling off a prank at school, Goofy unintentionally sabotages his son’s love life by dragging Max on a cross country trip in an attempt to reconnect and bond. It proves to be an illuminating experience for both of them.

Descendants (2015)

63%

6.2/10

g

112m

Genre

Family, Music, Adventure, Comedy, Fantasy, TV Movie

Stars

Dove Cameron, Cameron Boyce, Booboo Stewart

Directed by

Kenny Ortega

Watch on Disney+

In the world of Descendants, the Disney heroes have established a new nation called Auradon, and settled down to have children. The villains are isolated on the Isle of the Lost with children of their own. Shortly before his coronation, the son of Beauty and the Beast, Ben (Mitchell Hope), invites Maleficent’s daughter, Mal (Dove Cameron); Jafar’s son, Jay (Booboo Stewart), Cruella de Vil’s son, Carlos (Cameron Boyce); and the Evil Queen’s daughter, Evie (Sofia Carson); the chance to live in Auradon away from their evil parents. Maleficent (Kristin Chenoweth) sees it as a chance for revenge. However, the loyalty the kids have for their villainous parents is tested as they find their true selves in Auradon.

Official Trailer | Descendants

Holes (2003)

71%

7/10

pg

117m

Genre

Adventure, Family, Drama, Comedy

Stars

Shia LaBeouf, Khleo Thomas, Sigourney Weaver

Directed by

Andrew Davis

Watch on Disney+

Shia LaBeouf made his big screen debut in the live-action Disney film, Holes. LaBeouf plays Stanley Yelnats IV, a teenager who is unjustly convicted of stealing a pair of sneakers. Stanley is sentenced to 18 months at Camp Green Lake, where he and other youth offenders are constantly forced to dig holes in the desert by a corrupt warden, Louise Walker (Sigourney Weaver). As Stanley befriends Hector “Zero” Zeroni (Khleo Thomas) and other prisoners, he discovers that the warden is searching for a lost treasure that has ties to his own family history.

Life with Mikey (1993)

50%

5.6/10

pg

91m

Genre

Comedy, Family

Stars

Michael J. Fox, Christina Vidal, Nathan Lane

Directed by

James Lapine

Watch on Disney+

The parallels between Michael J. Fox and his character, Mikey Chapman, are unmistakable in Life With Mikey. Both Fox and Mikey are former child actors who rocketed to stardom on the back of a hit sitcom. But in this story, Mikey has given up on acting to become a talent agent for child actors. When a young girl named Angie Vega (Christina Vidal) picks his pocket, Mikey believes that he’s stumbled upon the next big star. But getting Angie her big break is much easier said than done.

Coco (2017)

81%

8.4/10

pg

105m

Genre

Family, Animation, Fantasy, Music, Comedy, Adventure

Stars

Anthony Gonzalez, Gael García Bernal, Benjamin Bratt

Directed by

Lee Unkrich

Watch on Disney+

Pixar may no longer have the perfect batting average with its films, but when the studio is on top of its game, not even Disney Animation can match its emotional impact. Coco is a perfect example of this, as well as Pixar’s push towards greater onscreen representation. Within the film, Miguel (Anthony Gonzalez) is a 12-year-old boy who dreams of being a musician. After learning that his grandfather is the great Ernesto de la Cruz (Benjamin Bratt), Miguel steals a guitar from a mausoleum and soon finds himself cursed and stuck in the land of the dead. To return to his living family, Miguel will have to reconcile with dead relatives including Hector (Gael García Bernal), a man who is desperate to reach his elderly daughter before she forgets about him.

Coco - Official US Trailer

Pete's Dragon (2016)

71%

6.7/10

pg

103m

Genre

Adventure, Family, Fantasy

Stars

But one day, he meets Alberto, an underwater boy who has discovered that all the underwater people turn into normal land people once they leave the water. As such, he’s led a wonderful life above the water, which he introduces to Luca. But they must not reveal to the townspeople that they’re from beneath the ocean.

Almost 20 years after its release, Finding Nemo remains a modern animated classic, unparalleled when compared to more recent entries in the genre. The movie takes viewers into the vast ocean, where finding oneself (and each other) is no easy task. Where Finding Nemo succeeds the most is introducing a wealth of unique characters, each more intriguing than the next and each worth rooting for in spades. Viewers of a certain age know the P. Sherman 42 Wallaby Way address by a heart and never has there been a more important time to remember to “just keep swimming.” Finding Nemo was the first Pixar film to score Best Animated Feature honors at the Academy Awards and its decent follow-up, Finding Dory, is available on Disney+ as well.

Do you want to build a snowman? Let it go already, Anna! If you haven’t already seen Frozen and its sequel, you would probably still understand those references, because the Walt Disney Pictures classic quickly became one of the most ubiquitous films of the last decade. And frankly, it lives up to the hype. The characters are well fleshed out, the humor is on point and the songs are ridiculously catchy. You will cry and laugh at least once while watching this movie; age, gender, ethnicity won’t be factors that prevent that from happening. Kristen Bell, the voice of Anna, and Idina Menzel, who voices Elsa, are perfectly cast, as is Josh Gad as lovable oaf snowman Olaf. Watching this movie on merit alone is worth it, but if for no other reason, watch it so that you have something to talk to about with children at the Thanksgiving table.

Based on the 1959 Rodgers & Hammerstein stage musical of the same name, director Robert Wise’s The Sound of Music is a lush and time-tested filmed adaptation that delights to this day. It stars Julie Andrews as the free-spirited Maria, a nun in training. Maria’s superiors fear her open-minded nature will lead her astray. Thus, Maria is assigned to be governess to the seven children of a retired naval commander, Captain von Trapp (Christopher Plummer). While her initial welcome to the von Trapp manor is anything but warm, Maria soon wins the affections of the seven children, as well as their father, by way of her chin-up attitude and musical abilities. A musical for the ages, The Sound of Music is a Technicolor marvel to behold.

While not Disney’s first cinematic foray into the jungle (The Jungle Book came first), Tarzan stands as one of the company’s most resonant animated works, thanks to its heartfelt narrative, playful characters, and powerful original score by Phil Collins. Taking place in the late 1800s, an orphaned English boy is taken in by a pack of gorillas and is raised as one of them. He does his best to fit in with his fellow mammals, despite his human leanings, but the world of the jungle is turned upside down by the arrival of an English researcher, Porter, his daughter Jane (Minnie Driver), and their blood-hungry escort, a rifle-touting hunter named Clayton. Can Tarzan protect his primate kin from the trophy-room villainy of Clayton while embracing his love for Jane? Give this Disney flick a spin to find out.

It’s tough being a toy, especially when your fragile sense of self is thrown into question by the new kid in town. That’s the basic premise of Pixar’s 1995 smash hit Toy Story. Woody (voiced by Tom Hanks) is the celebrated leader of his human Andy’s posse of bedroom toys. When Andy receives the all-new Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) for his birthday, the gang begins favoring the space ranger action figure, sending Woody into a jealous rage. After a sudden accident, Buzz is thrust from Andy’s bedroom window and into the great world beyond, sending Woody and the other toys on a daring search-and-rescue mission. Featuring state-of-the-art animation, incredible voice work, and a great story filled with laughs and the warm fuzzies, Toy Story is a perfect flick for the whole family.

A tale as old as time and a long-held Disney favorite for many, this animated adaptation of the classic French text features the voice-over talents of Paige O’ Hara, Robby Benson, and Richard White, among others. After being hexed by an enchantress in disguise, a selfish prince is transformed into a horrific beast (Benson). Stowed away in his castle, the only thing that can return him to human form is true love. Belle (O’ Hara), a bookish girl from a nearby hamlet, descends upon the beast’s manor in search of her missing father. Holding Belle’s father prisoner, the Beast agrees to release him if Belle will take his place. What follows is a baby-stepped companionship between Belle and Beast. Could Belle be his hope for salvation?

While the world may not have been asking for a Mary Poppins follow-up, Disney’s decades-later sequel does its best to honor the renowned original while imbuing the narrative with all the modern sensibilities of a Disney film. Starring Emily Blunt as the titular Poppins, the film takes place decades after the original, with Michael and Jane Banks (Ben Whishaw and Karen Dotrice) now adults. When the bank is days away from foreclosing on their deceased father’s estate, Michael’s only hope are the certificates proving his inheritance. Right in the throes of this financial hardship, the ever-fleeting Mary Poppins returns out of the blue to aid the grown children along their journey to prove their worth.

After 500 years of peace from the dreaded Druun army, the land of Kumandra is under attack once more. Only, this time, there are no sacred dragons to ward off the mythic enemy. Raya (Kelly Marie Tran), the daughter of the great Chief Benja (Daniel Dae Kim), is the lone survivor of the vicious onslaught. In order to ward off the devilish Druun, the warrior must journey across Kumandra in search of the single-remaining dragon, Sisu (Awkwafina). Having been the being that contained the Druun years before, she’s the only hope for humankind. A spectacle of modern-day animation, Raya and the Last Dragon is a more than fitting entry in the Disney canon, dancing with tropes in an air-brushed fashion but delivering a full-fledged narrative with relatable characters, rich voice-over work, and incredible set-pieces.

Disney’s initial Mighty Ducks movie wasn’t a hit with critics, but it was a slap shot for audiences. The Mighty Ducks introduced viewers to Gordon Bombay (Emilio Estevez) a former hockey player turned successful lawyer. After an arrest for driving under the influence, Gordon is assigned to 500 hours of community service as the coach of a youth hockey team. Through the Ducks, Gordon rediscovers his passion for the game and proves that he has a lot to teach the next generation of players. Gordon also bonds with his young players and makes big sacrifices in order to be a better example for the team.

Nick Perry is a freelance writer who bounced from Hollywood to Silicon Beach to pajama pants. His work has been featured on Digital Trends, Good Morning America, Entrepreneur, Mashable, and more media outlets.

Blair Marnell has been an entertainment journalist for over 15 years. His bylines have appeared in Wizard Magazine, Geek Monthly, SYFY Wire, Superhero Hype, Collider, DC Universe, and the official sites for Star Trek and Marvel. He also lends his pop culture expertise to Digital Trends on a variety of TV, movie, and streaming features.

Holden is a writer with a focus on streaming service guides. He has also written content for Screen Rant and FanSided and is eagerly anticipating every Star Wars series set to debut in the coming years.

Dan is a passionate and multitalented content creator with experience in pop culture, entertainment, and sports. Throughout his career, Dan has been a writer, broadcaster, podcaster, editor, and social media manager. At Digital Trends, Dan covers film and television, from reviewing upcoming projects to interviewing actors and directors. Outside of Digital Trends, he has been an Oscar prognosticator since 2016 as well as a sportswriter with a special concentration in New York professional sports. Dan is still waiting for the New York Knicks to win a championship, but unfortunately, he will have to wait a lot longer for this dream to become a reality.
